title: Basic Epidemiology and Health Statistics
requirements: For students in MSc Health Services Management and PgD Health Services Management
description: This course serves as an introduction to epidemiology for students with health services or healthcare experience. The course gives a general overview of epidemiology and biostatistics, including theories and methodologies, and applications in health services management and other healthcare sectors. The course provides the basis for further studies.
outcome: Student should be able to: 1. appreciate the importance of epidemiology in public health and health services and its limitations 2. describe the various study designs, know their advantages and limitations and how to interpret their results 3. understand basic epidemiological theories, concepts, and methods as applied to health services 4. learn the valid methods for estimating the frequency of disease, and for comparing between groups and populations, learn possible biases and their control methods in the estimation and comparisons 5. apply quantitative methods to address practical public health and health services management issues 6. identify and appraise findings from health services research

title: Introduction to Epidemiology
requirements: For students in Master of Public Health, PgD in Public Health, MSc in Epidemiology & Biostatistics or PgD in Epidemiology & Biostatistics
description: This course will introduce basic epidemiology to students including introduction to epidemiology, applied health research methods, designing and conducting epidemiological studies (descriptive, case-control, cohort, clinical trials and meta-analysis).
outcome: Student should be able to: 1. appreciate the importance of epidemiology in clinical medicine as well as in public health 2. describe the various study designs, know their advantages and limitations and how to interpret their results 3. understand basic epidemiological theories, concepts, and methods as applied to health conditions 4. learn the valid methods for estimating the frequency of disease, the effect of a cause or a treatment, and for comparing between groups and populations 5. learn possible biases and their control methods in the estimation and comparisons 6. apply epidemiological methods to address practical health issues and understand their limitations 7. identify and appraise findings from epidemiological research for application

title: Epidemiology II
requirements: For students in Master of Public Health, PgD in Epidemiology & Biostatistics or MSc in Epidemiology & Biostatistics
description: This is an intermediate module which builds on the content of Introduction to Epidemiology (EPID5001). This module aims to provide students with further knowledge on cross sectional studies, cohort studies, randomized controlled trials, and systematic reviews.
outcome: 1. To acquire knowledge on intermediate design and bias reduction methods of cross sectional studies, cohort studies, randomized controlled trials, and systematic reviews2. Apply intermediate epidemiological concepts and techniques in the planning of epidemiologic studies
syllabus: 1. Cross sectional studies2. Systematic review: literature search and study selection3. Concepts of RCT –beyond the basics4. Case examples of RCT (design, data analysis and interpretation)5. Systematic review: data extraction and risk of bias assessment6. Longitudinal Cohort Studies I 7. Extensions to the design of case-control studies

title: Epidemiology III
requirements: For students in Master of Public Health, PgD in Epidemiology & Biostatistics or MSc in Epidemiology & Biostatistics
description: Students shall learn how to conduct common statistical analyses of epidemiological data by using SPSS or other statistical software and to prepare scientific reports for publication. Sessions will consist of brief introduction of the concepts, computer demonstration and data analysis practicum. The session on reporting will be introduce international guidelines for drafting publications for systematic reviews and randomized trials.
outcome: Conduct data cleaning, data management and analysis for an epidemiological study using statistical software Compare pros and cons of different analytical methods  Be able to present data in tables and figures in proper format for publishing in peer-reviewed journal  Acquire skills in using reporting guidelines for systematic reviews and randomized trials
syllabus: 1. Data Management with SPSS (I)2. Data Management with SPSS (II)3. Systematic review: data analysis4. Systematic review: PRISMA reporting guideline5. Tutorial on RCT data analysis6. Longitudinal Cohort studies II7. Longitudinal Cohort studies III8. Data analysis of Case control studies9. Critical appraisal of a case-control study10. Diagnostic accuracy study and randomized controlled trial for screening: data analysis11. Data presentation and visualization
required_readings: To be given by individual lecturers in class

title: Appraisal of the Methods of Epidemiological Studies
requirements: For students in MSc/PgD in Epidemiology and Biostatistics, MPhil in Public Health, PhD in Public Health, Master of Public Health, PgD in Public Health, MSc/PgD in Health Services Management, MSc/PgD in Health Promotion and Behavioural Health
description: The course will include a series of tutorials for appraising the methods of commonly used epidemiological study designs. In each tutorial, a published study of a specific design (e.g., randomized controlled trial) will be selected and presented and questions regarding the methods of the study will be asked. Students need to carefully read and discuss the questions beforehand and further discuss with the tutor and peers in the class.
outcome: After these tutorials, students are expected to: 1. have a good idea of what a real epidemiological study is like; 2. know how the methods are implemented in real setting; 3. appreciate compromises in the methods in real studies;  4. know how to appraise the results, validity and generalizability of a study.
syllabus: Introduction and General GuidelineEcological study Clinical trial/ RCTCase-control studyCohort studyCross-sectional studySystematic reviewPrognostic studyExamination (TBC)

title: Selected Topics in Epidemiology
requirements: For students in Master of Public Health and MSc in Epidemiology & Biostatistics
description: The course involves a series of guest lecture seminars in which methodological aspects of various areas of epidemiological research are discussed and elaborated.

title: Nutritional Epidemiology
requirements: For students in Master of Public Health, MSc in Epidemiology & Biostatistics
description: In this course, you will learn about the methods used to assess dietary intakes and how to overcome limitations in assessing such a complex ‘exposure’. Nutrient intakes and dietary patterns in different population groups will be illustrated and key diet-disease associations will be presented. Finally, some of the challenges in interpreting nutritional epidemiology evidence and practical issues in communicating findings will be covered.

title: Practice in Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
requirements: For students in Master of Public Health, MSc in Epidemiology & Biostatistics
description: This course is an advanced module for students who are interested in conducting systematic review and meta-analysis. It emphasizes on practical knowledge and skills needed for doing this kind of research: performing exhaustive literature search to identify relevant studies, extracting data from eligible studies, assessing risk of bias, synthesizing data, including meta-analysis, presenting results graphically and tabularly, investigating heterogeneity and potential biases, and publishing manuscripts in peer-reviewed journals. Tutorial materials will be distributed to students for their in-class exercises. Students will be enabled to master the essential skills for doing systematic review and meta-analysis by the end of this module.

title: Digital Epidemiology
requirements:
For students in MSc in Epidemiology & Biostatistics, Master of Public Health
Pre-requisite: EPID5001, BIOS5001
description: This advanced module introduces the concept of digital epidemiology with new forms of health data and real examples for disease management. The traditional epidemiology consists of studying various risk factors of the general population to study incidence and prevalence. The field of digital epidemiology is new, but has been growing rapidly with the increasing amounts of data generated on the internet, wearable devices, and mobile APPs. Students will explore the feasibility of applications through different real digital examples, including the consideration with data privacy and protection.
outcome: Explain the concepts of digital epidemiology and the associated applications of Big Data Design for the framework of epidemiological studies with the use of digital health data  Suggest the ways of interpretation for different types of digital health data Plan for the health applications with wearable devices and mobile APPs
syllabus: 1. Overview of Digital Epidemiology2. Electronic Health Records3. Health Data from the Community4. Social Media for Disease Management5. Big Data and Artificial Intelligence6. Supercomputer and Computing Servers7. Wearable Devices and Mobile APPs
required_readings: Mainly from academic publication. A full list will be ready before the lecture starts.

title: Advanced Infectious Disease Epidemiology
requirements:
For students in MSc Epidemiology and Biostatistics and Master of Public Health
Pre-requisite: EPID5001
description: This course is designed to enable post-graduate students who have a background in infectious diseases epidemiology to practice their skills in the real-life problem in infectious disease epidemiology. Contemporary statistical and mathematical methods will be introduced for the study of infectious disease epidemiological data. The course is illustrated with many topical examples including COVID-19, SARS, and influenza.
outcome: Student should be able to: To acquire knowledge on infectious disease epidemiology To distinguish different modes of infectious disease transmission from the epidemiological data collected, and, interpret their findings and confirm their hypothesis; To apply intermediate statistical and mathematical model to real life practical problems in infectious disease epidemiology. To evaluate the control measures implemented
syllabus: 1.    Basic epidemic theory2.    Routes of transmission of infectious diseases3.    Overseas experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic and other infectious disease (I)4.    Introduction of mathematical compartmental model and its application 5.    Overseas experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic and other infectious disease (II)6.    Local experiences of the COVID-19 pandemic and other infectious disease (II)
required_readings: To be provided by teachers in each session
